John, yeah, when folks enable TLS for the undercloud, they expect most services will go through this endpoint (it's not possible for all services, e.g. ironic/ironic-inspector), but most of them do."}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-02 14:55:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> John, yeah, when folks enable TLS for the undercloud, they expect
 > most services will go through this endpoint (it's not possible for
 > all services, e.g. ironic/ironic-inspector), but most of them do.

but is the internalURL on https as well? and if not, why?"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-08 17:52:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-08 17:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-08 17:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Juan, with this we explicitly point to the internal endpoint specifically from the deployment and suppport workflows, can you revisit it?'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-08-08 18:03:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I thought we had agreed not to do that. Could it at least be configurable, and default to public?'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-09 12:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> I thought we had agreed not to do that. Could it at least be
 > configurable, and default to public?

Juan it defaults to public except for the deployment workflow, I think this does what you are suggesting? Unless I misunderstood where you wanted to make if configurable'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-08-09 12:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So, I wanted to keep it as it is (defaulting to public) and make it configurable, so folks that REALLY need it can switch to internal endpoints.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2018-08-09 14:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-08-09 21:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> So, I wanted to keep it as it is (defaulting to public) and make it
 > configurable, so folks that REALLY need it can switch to internal
 > endpoints.

Hey Jaun,

Thanks for reviewing this patch. I think that by keeping it "as it is" you mean before this change which switches the default to internal. I also think that you're OK with this change so far as it makes the setting configurable but that we're now talking about what the default should be. If I misunderstood, then please let me know.

My concern is that defaulting to public results in a more complicated default deployment. The user has to:

1. inject a trust anchor
2. if they're using spine/leaf they need to inject extra routes back to the public end point

The users don't notice they need to do 1 and 2 unless they add features which depend on the access.yaml workbook. I think this makes it not a good default because they have to learn about the above the hard way. I.e. when the feature they add which depends on access.yaml unexpectedly breaks. And when this happens it doesn't make sense to them because the other UC/OC communications, which got them further along in the deployment, were able to use the internal end point. For those users, they shouldn't know they need to opt out of the public end point if they don't want the extra security benefit. So, because it results in something more complicated and unexpected, I think it's something a user should opt into.

The complication of using the internal end point is worth it for users who do want the additional security benefit. E.g. users who opt in to choose to inject a trust anchor when they deploy because they understand what they're opting into. When they do this, they should also opt into using the public endpoint too.

For these reasons, I think we should default to internal and those who want the extra security should override the default to use the encrypted public endpoint. So I agree with you that "when folks enable TLS for the undercloud, they expect most services will go through this endpoint". I just think they should enable the secure endpoint too when they enable TLS.

If the majority prefer to keep the public endpoint the default, then I think we should add a warning to our documentation [0][1] so the user has some examples to follow if they do run into the complexity above.

Respectfully,
  John

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/routed_spine_leaf_network.html

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/ssl.html'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-08-10 03:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I feel that the result of moving towards an insecure default will be just to punish folks that want to opt for a more secure option. All this does is add even another extra step if we want to move towards having secure defaults, and this IMO is unacceptable. Even for OSP15 I hope to get TLS by default for the overcloud even. Injecting the undercloud CA is even automated for OSP14, so there is no extra step there if you opt for the secure option.

 
> > So, I wanted to keep it as it is (defaulting to public) and make
 > it
 > > configurable, so folks that REALLY need it can switch to internal
 > > endpoints.
 > 
 > Hey Jaun,
 > 
 > Thanks for reviewing this patch. I think that by keeping it "as it
 > is" you mean before this change which switches the default to
 > internal. I also think that you're OK with this change so far as it
 > makes the setting configurable but that we're now talking about
 > what the default should be. If I misunderstood, then please let me
 > know.
 > 
 > My concern is that defaulting to public results in a more
 > complicated default deployment. The user has to:
 > 
 > 1. inject a trust anchor
 > 2. if they're using spine/leaf they need to inject extra routes
 > back to the public end point
 > 
 > The users don't notice they need to do 1 and 2 unless they add
 > features which depend on the access.yaml workbook. I think this
 > makes it not a good default because they have to learn about the
 > above the hard way. I.e. when the feature they add which depends on
 > access.yaml unexpectedly breaks. And when this happens it doesn't
 > make sense to them because the other UC/OC communications, which
 > got them further along in the deployment, were able to use the
 > internal end point. For those users, they shouldn't know they need
 > to opt out of the public end point if they don't want the extra
 > security benefit. So, because it results in something more
 > complicated and unexpected, I think it's something a user should
 > opt into.
 > 
 > The complication of using the internal end point is worth it for
 > users who do want the additional security benefit. E.g. users who
 > opt in to choose to inject a trust anchor when they deploy because
 > they understand what they're opting into. When they do this, they
 > should also opt into using the public endpoint too.
 > 
 > For these reasons, I think we should default to internal and those
 > who want the extra security should override the default to use the
 > encrypted public endpoint. So I agree with you that "when folks
 > enable TLS for the undercloud, they expect most services will go
 > through this endpoint". I just think they should enable the secure
 > endpoint too when they enable TLS.
 > 
 > If the majority prefer to keep the public endpoint the default,
 > then I think we should add a warning to our documentation [0][1] so
 > the user has some examples to follow if they do run into the
 > complexity above.
 > 
 > Respectfully,
 > John
 > 
 > [0] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/routed_spine_leaf_network.html
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/ssl.html'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-08-10 05:05:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-05-04 22:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning this 9-month old patch. We can restore if we need to.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-02 11:24:14.000000000', 'message': 'Changes get_endpoint_for_project default from publicURL to internalURL

Defaulting to publicURL forces all connections to go over SSL and all
clients to trust the undercloud certificate when self-signed.

This submission changes the default to look for the internalURL and
adds a parameter to make specific calls use a different endpoint.

Change-Id: I187dbe6585461f21e32bbd9fa1451fab73ae7e7e
Closes-Bug: #1785045
'}, {'created': '2018-08-08 17:52:38.000000000', 'message': 'Makes endpoint_type used by get_endpoint_for_project configurable

Adds a parameter to make specific calls use a different endpoint
and updates support and deployment workflows to use the internal
endpoint.

Change-Id: I187dbe6585461f21e32bbd9fa1451fab73ae7e7e
Closes-Bug: #1785045
'}, {'created': '2018-08-08 17:53:56.000000000', 'message': 'Makes endpoint_type used by get_endpoint_for_project configurable

Adds a parameter to make specific calls use a different endpoint
and updates support and deployment workflows to use the internal
endpoint.

Change-Id: I187dbe6585461f21e32bbd9fa1451fab73ae7e7e
Closes-Bug: #1785045
'}, {'created': '2018-08-09 14:38:19.000000000', 'message': 'Makes endpoint_type used by get_endpoint_for_project configurable

Adds a parameter to make specific calls use a different endpoint
and updates support and deployment workflows to use the internal
endpoint.

Change-Id: I187dbe6585461f21e32bbd9fa1451fab73ae7e7e
Closes-Bug: #1785045
'}]
commit_message:
Makes endpoint_type used by get_endpoint_for_project configurable

Adds a parameter to make specific calls use a different endpoint
and updates support and deployment workflows to use the internal
endpoint.

Change-Id: I187dbe6585461f21e32bbd9fa1451fab73ae7e7e
Closes-Bug: #1785045

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-01-16 17:58:16.000000000', 'message': "Make sure target exists before running it

By generating the targets list once prior to running the targets, there
is the possibility that a script doesn't exist anymore or doesn't have
the right permissions by the time it is called.

See for instance [1] that deletes files from the target_dir.

This commit ensures the target exists and is executable before trying to
run it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-puppet-elements/blob/41ee9895d544ff9809bf5a2b47182ccfbbae4c0f/elements/hiera/os-refresh-config/configure.d/10-hiera-disable
Change-Id: I746b5c89082fedc01b32ad00e573a25f8c4201c0
"}]
commit_message:
Make sure target exists before running it

By generating the targets list once prior to running the targets, there
is the possibility that a script doesn't exist anymore or doesn't have
the right permissions by the time it is called.

See for instance [1] that deletes files from the target_dir.

This commit ensures the target exists and is executable before trying to
run it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-puppet-elements/blob/41ee9895d544ff9809bf5a2b47182ccfbbae4c0f/elements/hiera/os-refresh-config/configure.d/10-hiera-disable
Change-Id: I746b5c89082fedc01b32ad00e573a25f8c4201c0

commit_message:
py3: port s3api

Drive-by: When passing a list or tuple to swob.Response as an app_iter,
check that it's full of byte strings.

Change-Id: Ifc35aacb2e45004f74c871f08ff3c52bc57c1463

commit_message:
Fix is_neutron_legacy_enabled function

This function will now first filter out all "neutron-" strings from
DISABLED_SERVICES list before looking for "neutron" string in it.

Change-Id: I5cab6a3be553713e1257599fb72042c6001f2672
Close-Bug: #1824884

commit_message:
Remove log translation and i18n

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

Change-Id: I9ddb6595fc52e46ed8844e39d2fa71029c90b65c
Closes-Bug: #1674567

commit_message:
Add backend to location metadata

Adds 'backend' to location metadata if multistire enabled and none
supplied. Queries glance_store to find the first configured backend
capable of handling the URL.

Change-Id: I0a6901ba2f5d1c26ac5d9df561bf9057fdbe0e8e
Closes-Bug: #1802587
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/618932

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-04 18:59:09.000000000', 'message': 'Update .zuul.yaml

Remove publish-to-pypi, it should stay in project-config so that tagging
of repos with multiple branches works, see
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html#central-config-exceptions

Remove names, this should never be used - and is a noop. It will cause
harm in case the repo gets renamed.

Change-Id: I45f92fbf282afab06a80db5cd5b311db76344737
'}]
commit_message:
Update .zuul.yaml

Remove publish-to-pypi, it should stay in project-config so that tagging
of repos with multiple branches works, see
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html#central-config-exceptions

Remove names, this should never be used - and is a noop. It will cause
harm in case the repo gets renamed.

Change-Id: I45f92fbf282afab06a80db5cd5b311db76344737

commit_message:
Add image type capability flags and trait conversions

This makes the base virt driver define capability flags for each of the
glance-defined image types. It also adds a capability-to-trait mapping
for each, causing any driver that supports a given image type to expose
the corresponding trait.

Related to blueprint request-filter-image-types

Change-Id: Id2912a46dddee3d63ce373e4d280fad79d0128a8

_get_ports_query add filters after a get_collection. If limits are
passed to applied to the query, then no additional filter is allowed.
This patch extracts an eventual limit argument, to apply it only after
the additional filters.

Change-Id: I83394394860d10e27379efe0356d0fa9c567140e

commit_message:
Get ports query: extract limit and use it only at the end.

_get_ports_query add filters after a get_collection. If limits are
passed to applied to the query, then no additional filter is allowed.
This patch extracts an eventual limit argument, to apply it only after
the additional filters.

Change-Id: I83394394860d10e27379efe0356d0fa9c567140e
Closes-Bug: #1826186
(cherry picked from commit cf8f3326be14d30456b20e4d1a55a36762daa550)

Building on Ib440f4f2e484312af5f393722363846f6c95b760 we should always
attempt to disconnect volumes from the host when exceptions are thrown
while attempting to attach a volume to a domain. This was previously
done for generic exceptions but not for libvirtError exceptions.

Closes-Bug: #1826523
Change-Id: If21230869826c992e7d0398434b9a4b255940213
(cherry picked from commit 091a910576d9b580678f1881fffa425ab4632f48)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Always disconnect volumes after libvirtError exceptions

Building on Ib440f4f2e484312af5f393722363846f6c95b760 we should always
attempt to disconnect volumes from the host when exceptions are thrown
while attempting to attach a volume to a domain. This was previously
done for generic exceptions but not for libvirtError exceptions.

Closes-Bug: #1826523
Change-Id: If21230869826c992e7d0398434b9a4b255940213
(cherry picked from commit 091a910576d9b580678f1881fffa425ab4632f48)

commit_message:
Move redelegation fields out of extras

The trust SQL backend uses the extras column to store the
redeletegated_trust_id and redelegation_count info. It's
better to make them first class citizens and give them
their own columns.

This change does not add redelegation_trust_id to the trust schema
because this value is set by the token context, not by the user. We also
remove it from the api-ref example to avoid confusion about this.

Co-Authored-By: David Stanek <dstanek@dstanek.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Makarov <amakarov@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: If496152e40d2213a03faad5645667220fddfcf62

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I1e099545e642712ab8d99b9f8e4484ca9cb108c5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-19 21:29:12.000000000', 'message': "versioned_writes: stop trying to catch HTTPPreconditionFailed

* We just caught it to raise another one
* On newer versions of python, we wouldn't actually catch
  anything, because HTTPPreconditionFailed is not an instance
  of BaseException -- it's a partial function application
  which when called will return an exception.

Change-Id: Ia44e832e4198e75f3337884c4612f4e9fe3b9e0b
"}]
commit_message:
versioned_writes: stop trying to catch HTTPPreconditionFailed

* We just caught it to raise another one
* On newer versions of python, we wouldn't actually catch
  anything, because HTTPPreconditionFailed is not an instance
  of BaseException -- it's a partial function application
  which when called will return an exception.

Change-Id: Ia44e832e4198e75f3337884c4612f4e9fe3b9e0b

commit_message:
Fix resource leaks in EndPointGroupsTest

Test cases were creating services at the test case
scope and not add them to addCleanup method.

Change-Id: I390f9e013930477f32c537191adbef37e1b4dd1c

I am not the author of this assertion, although interestingly I did agree with it at the time:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523554/6/nova/virt/images.py

I'm not sure how much thought I gave to the performance, though. I was most likely just thinking about safety."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-03-05 16:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Here's my current thinking on this. Health Warning: This is ill-informed, as this is not an area of expertise.

The primary driver for using cache=none is to avoid a performance hit to VMs by evicting their pages from the same cache. If we can't do that, but writethrough and writeback are going to put a bunch of stuff into the cache that we don't need. Both of them are crash-safe, because they both fdatasync() on completion. writeback is faster according to kashyap's measurement, which is also intuitively correct as it can combine writes. So:

* cache=none: No cache impact on other VMs, presumably same write performance as writethrough (could measure this)
* cache=writethrough: Uses host cache, impacts VMs use of same cache, poor write performance.
* cache=writeback: Uses host cache, impacts VMs use of same cache, good wrote performance.

If the above is correct, then if cache=none isn't possible due to fs limitations, cache=writeback would seem to be the obvious choice.

But as I said at the top, this isn't an area of my expertise. It would be good to get some validation of the above."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-03-06 15:45:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Here's my current thinking on this. Health Warning: This is
 > ill-informed, as this is not an area of expertise.
 > 
 > The primary driver for using cache=none is to avoid a performance
 > hit to VMs by evicting their pages from the same cache. If we can't
 > do that, but writethrough and writeback are going to put a bunch of
 > stuff into the cache that we don't need. Both of them are
 > crash-safe, because they both fdatasync() on completion. writeback
 > is faster according to kashyap's measurement, which is also
 > intuitively correct as it can combine writes. So:
 > 
 > * cache=none: No cache impact on other VMs, presumably same write
 > performance as writethrough (could measure this)

As discussed on IRC, the above is incorrect — 'writethrough' is debilitatingly slow, because it calls fsync() after *every* write -- which is also why it so crash-safe (it doesn't keep anything in the "write cache").

 > * cache=writethrough: Uses host cache, impacts VMs use of same
 > cache, poor write performance.

Yes, as you noted on IRC: "writethrough = write to cache, sync after every write, sync on completion"

 > * cache=writeback: Uses host cache, impacts VMs use of same cache,
 > good wrote performance.
 > 
 > If the above is correct, then if cache=none isn't possible due to
 > fs limitations, cache=writeback would seem to be the obvious
 > choice.

For the above, I'll quote QEMU Block Layer developer Kevin Wolf:

[quote]
If your guest OS really sucks and doesn't correctly issue flushes where data must be safe on disk, that would be one of the few cases where you could consider cache=writethrough. But then the O_DIRECT-based alternative to 'writethrough' isn't 'cache=none', which doesn't provide this safety either, but 'cache=directsync'.
[/quote]

 > But as I said at the top, this isn't an area of my expertise. It
 > would be good to get some validation of the above.

Thanks for the review.

Before submitting this patch, FWIW, I got this also reviewed with Kevin Wolf (who also gave this patch a "Looks-good-to-me'd-by").'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-03-06 16:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-03-07 10:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I dug into QEMU's code base to quadruple-confirm that 'qemu-img convert' ends up calling fsync(2) to flush the data to disk, after successful image conversion.  Here is the final call trace:

- In block/io.c, we begin with: bdrv_flush()  --> bdrv_flush_co_entry()
  --> bdrv_co_flush().

- Then:  bdrv_co_flush() --> bdrv_co_flush_to_disk() -->
  raw_co_flush_to_disk(), which sets handle_aiocb_flush() as a callback
  function.

- And finally: handle_aiocb_flush() --> qemu_fdatasync() --> fsync(2)."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-03-14 18:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-04 15:00:27.000000000', 'message': 'qemu: Make disk image conversion dramatically faster

tl;dr: Use 'writeback' instead of 'writethrough' as the cache mode of
the target image for `qemu-img convert`.  Two reasons: (a) if the image
conversion completes succesfully, then 'writeback' calls fsync(2) to
safely write data to the physical disk; and (b) 'writeback' makes the
image conversion a lot (at least 15 times, in some cases) faster.

Back-of-the-envelope benchmark (on an SSD)
------------------------------------------

(Ran this three times each.)

With 'writethrough':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writethrough -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)
    real    1m43.470s
    user    0m8.310s
    sys     0m3.661s

With 'writeback':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writeback  -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 5-Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)

    real    0m7.390s
    user    0m5.179s
    sys     0m1.780s

The 'writeback' cache mode is at least _15_ times faster!

Details
-------

Nova commit e6ce9557f8 ("qemu-img do not use cache=none if no O_DIRECT
support") was introduced to make Nova instances boot on filesystems that
don't support 'O_DIRECT' (which bypasses the host page cache and flush
data directly to the disk), such as 'tmpfs'.  In doing so it introduced
the 'writethrough' cache for the target image for `qemu-img convert`.

This patch proposes to change that to 'writeback'.  Let's addresses the
"safety" concern:

  "What about data integrity in the event of a host crash (especially
   on shared file systems such as NFS)?"

Answer: If the host crashes mid-way during image conversion, then
neither "data integrity" nor the cache mode in use matters.  But if the
image conversion completes _succesfully_, then 'writeback' will safely
write the data to the physical disk, just as 'writethough' does.

So we are as safe as we can; but with the extra benefit of image
conversion being much faster.

        * * *

The `qemu-img convert` command defaults to 'cache=writeback' for the
source image.  And 'cache=unsafe' for the target, because if `qemu-img`
"crashes during the conversion, the user will throw away the broken.
output file anyway and start over"[1].

Upstream `qemu-img convert` supports[2] fsync() for the target image
since QEMU 1.1 (2012).

[1] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=1bd8e175
    -- "qemu-img convert: Use cache=unsafe for output image"
[2] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=80ccf93b
    -- "qemu-img: let 'qemu-img convert' flush data"

Change-Id: I574be2b629aaff23556e25f8db0d740105be6f07
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Noticed-and-reviewed-by: Kevin Wolf <kwolf@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-03-04 17:57:19.000000000', 'message': 'qemu: Make disk image conversion dramatically faster

tl;dr: Use 'writeback' instead of 'writethrough' as the cache mode of
the target image for `qemu-img convert`.  Two reasons: (a) if the image
conversion completes succesfully, then 'writeback' calls fsync() to
safely write data to the physical disk; and (b) 'writeback' makes the
image conversion a _lot_ faster.

Back-of-the-envelope "benchmark" (on an SSD)
--------------------------------------------

(Ran both the tests thrice each.)

With 'writethrough':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writethrough -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)
    real    1m43.470s
    user    0m8.310s
    sys     0m3.661s

With 'writeback':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writeback  -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 5-Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)

    real    0m7.390s
    user    0m5.179s
    sys     0m1.780s

I.e. ~103 seconds of elapsed wall-clock time for 'writethrough' vs ~7
seconds for 'writeback' -- IOW, 'writeback' is nearly _15_ times faster!

Details
-------

Nova commit e6ce9557f8 ("qemu-img do not use cache=none if no O_DIRECT
support") was introduced to make instances boot on filesystems that
don't support 'O_DIRECT' (which bypasses the host page cache and flushes
data directly to the disk), such as 'tmpfs'.  In doing so it introduced
the 'writethrough' cache for the target image for `qemu-img convert`.

This patch proposes to change that to 'writeback'.

Let's addresses the 'safety' concern:

  "What about data integrity in the event of a host crash (especially
   on shared file systems such as NFS)?"

Answer: If the host crashes mid-way during image conversion, then
neither "data integrity" nor the cache mode in use matters.  But if the
image conversion completes _succesfully_, then 'writeback' will safely
write the data to the physical disk, just as 'writethough' does.

So we are as safe as we can, but with the extra benefit of image
conversion being _much_ faster.

        * * *

The `qemu-img convert` command defaults to 'cache=writeback' for the
source image.  And 'cache=unsafe' for the target, because if `qemu-img`
"crashes during the conversion, the user will throw away the broken.
output file anyway and start over"[1].  And `qemu-img convert`
supports[2] fsync() for the target image since QEMU 1.1 (2012).

[1] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=1bd8e175
    -- "qemu-img convert: Use cache=unsafe for output image"
[2] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=80ccf93b
    -- "qemu-img: let 'qemu-img convert' flush data"

Change-Id: I574be2b629aaff23556e25f8db0d740105be6f07
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Looks-good-to-me'd-by: Kevin Wolf <kwolf@redhat.com>

Back-of-the-envelope "benchmark" (on an SSD)
--------------------------------------------

(Ran both the tests thrice each; version: qemu-img-2.11.0)

With 'writethrough':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writethrough -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)
    real    1m43.470s
    user    0m8.310s
    sys     0m3.661s

With 'writeback':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writeback  -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 5-Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)

    real    0m7.390s
    user    0m5.179s
    sys     0m1.780s

I.e. ~103 seconds of elapsed wall-clock time for 'writethrough' vs. ~7
seconds for 'writeback' -- IOW, 'writeback' is nearly _15_ times faster!

Details
-------

Nova commit e6ce9557f84cdcdf4ffdd12ce73a008c96c7b94a ("qemu-img do not
use cache=none if no O_DIRECT support") was introduced to make instances
boot on filesystems that don't support 'O_DIRECT' (which bypasses the
host page cache and flushes data directly to the disk), such as 'tmpfs'.
In doing so it introduced the 'writethrough' cache for the target image
for `qemu-img convert`.

This patch proposes to change that to 'writeback'.

Let's addresses the 'safety' concern:

  "What about data integrity in the event of a host crash (especially
   on shared file systems such as NFS)?"

Answer: If the host crashes mid-way during image conversion, then
neither "data integrity" nor the cache mode in use matters.  But if the
image conversion completes _succesfully_, then 'writeback' will safely
write the data to the physical disk, just as 'writethough' does.

So we are as safe as we can, but with the extra benefit of image
conversion being _much_ faster.

        * * *

The `qemu-img convert` command defaults to 'cache=writeback' for the
source image.  And 'cache=unsafe' for the target, because if `qemu-img`
"crashes during the conversion, the user will throw away the broken
output file anyway and start over"[1].  And `qemu-img convert`
supports[2] fsync() for the target image since QEMU 1.1 (2012).

[1] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=1bd8e175
    -- "qemu-img convert: Use cache=unsafe for output image"
[2] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=80ccf93b
    -- "qemu-img: let 'qemu-img convert' flush data"

Closes-Bug: #1818847

Change-Id: I574be2b629aaff23556e25f8db0d740105be6f07
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Looks-good-to-me'd-by: Kevin Wolf <kwolf@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
qemu: Make disk image conversion dramatically faster

tl;dr: Use 'writeback' instead of 'writethrough' as the cache mode of
the target image for `qemu-img convert`.  Two reasons: (a) if the image
conversion completes succesfully, then 'writeback' calls fsync() to
safely write data to the physical disk; and (b) 'writeback' makes the
image conversion a _lot_ faster.

Back-of-the-envelope "benchmark" (on an SSD)
--------------------------------------------

(Ran both the tests thrice each; version: qemu-img-2.11.0)

With 'writethrough':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writethrough -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)
    real    1m43.470s
    user    0m8.310s
    sys     0m3.661s

With 'writeback':

    $> time (qemu-img convert -t writeback  -f qcow2 -O raw \
            Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.qcow2 5-Fedora-Cloud-Base-29.raw)

    real    0m7.390s
    user    0m5.179s
    sys     0m1.780s

I.e. ~103 seconds of elapsed wall-clock time for 'writethrough' vs. ~7
seconds for 'writeback' -- IOW, 'writeback' is nearly _15_ times faster!

Details
-------

Nova commit e6ce9557f84cdcdf4ffdd12ce73a008c96c7b94a ("qemu-img do not
use cache=none if no O_DIRECT support") was introduced to make instances
boot on filesystems that don't support 'O_DIRECT' (which bypasses the
host page cache and flushes data directly to the disk), such as 'tmpfs'.
In doing so it introduced the 'writethrough' cache for the target image
for `qemu-img convert`.

This patch proposes to change that to 'writeback'.

Let's addresses the 'safety' concern:

  "What about data integrity in the event of a host crash (especially
   on shared file systems such as NFS)?"

Answer: If the host crashes mid-way during image conversion, then
neither "data integrity" nor the cache mode in use matters.  But if the
image conversion completes _succesfully_, then 'writeback' will safely
write the data to the physical disk, just as 'writethough' does.

So we are as safe as we can, but with the extra benefit of image
conversion being _much_ faster.

        * * *

The `qemu-img convert` command defaults to 'cache=writeback' for the
source image.  And 'cache=unsafe' for the target, because if `qemu-img`
"crashes during the conversion, the user will throw away the broken
output file anyway and start over"[1].  And `qemu-img convert`
supports[2] fsync() for the target image since QEMU 1.1 (2012).

[1] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=1bd8e175
    -- "qemu-img convert: Use cache=unsafe for output image"
[2] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=80ccf93b
    -- "qemu-img: let 'qemu-img convert' flush data"

Closes-Bug: #1818847

Change-Id: I574be2b629aaff23556e25f8db0d740105be6f07
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Looks-good-to-me'd-by: Kevin Wolf <kwolf@redhat.com>

I admit to feeling very stupid today so sorry if I'm missing something here.

The plan is to use the same syntax we use for required and forbidden traits in flavors (to express required and forbidden traits in placement) to add metadata to nova-side aggregates that will allow us discover a list of aggregates that allow us to use negative member_of queries against placement which will have synchronized aggregates with nova.

Is that right?

Are the similarities in syntax a good thing or a bad thing? The implication is that they are the same thing, but they aren't, are they?"}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-04-15 17:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I would like to make sure this approach would work for Ironic bare-metal nodes as well. Since they cannot be added to Nova aggregates, would an operator create an empty Nova host aggregate with the required trait and separately associate resource providers of bare-metal nodes to the corresponding placement aggregate?'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-04-16 09:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

> I admit to feeling very stupid today so sorry if I'm missing

 > 
 > The plan is to use the same syntax we use for required and
 > forbidden traits in flavors (to express required and forbidden
 > traits in placement) to add metadata to nova-side aggregates that
 > will allow us discover a list of aggregates that allow us to use
 > negative member_of queries against placement which will have
 > synchronized aggregates with nova.
 > 
 > Is that right?

I think you are right.

 > 
 > Are the similarities in syntax a good thing or a bad thing? The
 > implication is that they are the same thing, but they aren't, are
 > they?

1) we are talking about traits and I think the trait concept is the same both in the host aggregate and in the flavor. So I would not change that part of the syntax. The proposed host aggregate feature want to express that. An aggregate does not allow requests which does not have a specific trait. If I remove the double negative then it is: An aggregate requires some traits to be present in every request. Hence the "required" words seems appropriate to me. Or did I miss what part of the syntax you are questioning?

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-22 06:59:51.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/proposes to bp/placement-req-filter-forbidden-aggregates'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-22 21:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Yeah, I like this. This should be much more dynamically manageable, i.e. you set the filter in config and then everything else is managed via APIs (compute and placement) unlike the IsolatedHostsFilter. Just +1 for now since I've got some questions within."}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-04-27 02:51:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

Thank you Tushar! This looks good to me overall.
Soft -1 to clear the multiple traits behavior on L110 for the instance reservation. The others are nits.

I think this enables blazar to not force operators on setup to separate blazar managed hosts and non-blazar hosts and enables developers to remove the BlazarFilter doing like:

On host reservation Blazar
* creates that reservation’s specific aggregate with traits=<reservation id> and get that host in.

On instance reservation Blazar
* sets global instance reservation aggregate with traits=<reservation_id> and get that host in
* creates that reservation’s specific resource class and give that inventory to the host(’s child provider) 

@Pierre
I assume the instance reservation scheme above is used for ironic driver use cases, and I think that works because it uses not only aggregate but also the resource class approach. (resource class does added to not a service host but a resource provider of a compute node)
It would leave a small pain point though, that if one node is used for blazar, the other nodes on the same host service can’t be used as non-blazar hosts.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:07:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:11:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Support filtering of allocation_candidates by forbidden aggregates

This blueprint proposes to specify forbidden aggregates in the `member_of`
query parameter of the `GET /allocation_candidates` placement API.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603352

Change-Id: I1a94f50d42e57ff9d746e2f160a89dfab1978894
Implements: blueprint placement-req-filter-forbidden-aggregates

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I56c541c6afda611d10bb6d30af9aa6a86cf948c6

[{'created': '2018-01-26 21:02:04.000000000', 'message': 'add argparse conflict handler "ignore"

Update our version of ArgumentParser with a conflict resolution
handler called "ignore" to ignore options from commands if they would
conflict with options already registered. An error is reported if the
action associated with the option would not be registered at all
because all of its names conflict. A warning is reported for each
option string that is being ignored.

Change-Id: I99c62d5772017333136527f7f509c776623641a1
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add argparse conflict handler "ignore"

Update our version of ArgumentParser with a conflict resolution
handler called "ignore" to ignore options from commands if they would
conflict with options already registered. An error is reported if the
action associated with the option would not be registered at all
because all of its names conflict. A warning is reported for each
option string that is being ignored.

Change-Id: I99c62d5772017333136527f7f509c776623641a1
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-30 09:48:26.000000000', 'message': 'Use oslo_messaging_rpc_port for nova rpc healthchecks

With 405366fa32583e88c34417e5f46fa574ed8f4e98 the parameters RpcPort,
RpcUserName, RpcPassword and RpcUseSSL got deprecated and
nova::rabbitmq_port removed. As a result the healtcheck get called with
null parameter and fail.
We now get the global_config_settings from RabbitMQService and use
oslo_messaging_rpc_port for the healthcheck.

This is an addition to 8ff04029f5bc4cc2db4b3575229ce7bafb4eb358 for
the undercloud compute service.

Related-Bug: #1824805

Change-Id: Ic5f545b3bda571e028452d5c4123d9eca4493054
'}]
commit_message:
Use oslo_messaging_rpc_port for nova rpc healthchecks

With 405366fa32583e88c34417e5f46fa574ed8f4e98 the parameters RpcPort,
RpcUserName, RpcPassword and RpcUseSSL got deprecated and
nova::rabbitmq_port removed. As a result the healtcheck get called with
null parameter and fail.
We now get the global_config_settings from RabbitMQService and use
oslo_messaging_rpc_port for the healthcheck.

This is an addition to 8ff04029f5bc4cc2db4b3575229ce7bafb4eb358 for
the undercloud compute service.

Related-Bug: #1824805

Change-Id: Ic5f545b3bda571e028452d5c4123d9eca4493054

Depending on the version of $DIB_PYTHON_VERSION, we can either use pip /
pip3 to install glean.  This is helpful for newer OSes that might not
want to ship python2 (pip).

Change-Id: I25c5927a1eb55ee16b919dd64403184f335839b6
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Switch simple-init to support python3

Depending on the version of $DIB_PYTHON_VERSION, we can either use pip /
pip3 to install glean.  This is helpful for newer OSes that might not
want to ship python2 (pip).

Change-Id: I25c5927a1eb55ee16b919dd64403184f335839b6
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

https://github.com/openstack/keystone-specs/tree/master/specs/keystone/backlog'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-06-21 15:51:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Rather than trying to make tokens smaller (for PKI and PKIz which carry the catalog with them), I'd suggest we work to get Fernet the default. See comments inline"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-07-04 03:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

i'd like to see proof that the existing caching of the catalog on the server side is insufficient.

this is a very large change of behaviour for a critical path in keystone, and has moving parts in keystoneclient and keystonemiddleware. yes, you can opt into it with a config option, but i think it merits a bit more time to be baked"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-07-21 17:16:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2016-07-21 17:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

This is proposing a lot of new complexity for in exchange for a potential performance *loss*, because there's an additional hash and possibly persistence that needs to occur.

In our benchmarking, the most significant time impact of the service catalog is not in transmitting it, but in computing it for each token creation and validation request. Clients can already opt out of receiving the service catalog (and therefore prevent the server from computing it) using the ?nocatalog query parameter in both these cases, and if not, caching is a more effective solution on both the client (keystonemiddleware) and server (keystone)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-21 19:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints

We require six >= 1.11.0 due to our oslo.log dependency. Fix this. We
won't actually see this fix until we remove the use of 'tox_install.sh'
in I48f31084d595c44114391e046e5fe418c1fb787a.

Change-Id: I0f6ca974dc3055aad28638ef4b087a19935b4c29
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I48f31084d595c44114391e046e5fe418c1fb787a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I9ab70c74eeff509410d90f4305af116d83420f45

commit_message:
Enable not to print list header in TableFormatter and CSVLister.

This is a preparation to implementing "print list without header"
option, for example "neutron net-list --without-header".

Change-Id: Ic529cb5d45099881512aa768a2e8a1a194063e7f

At this point we should switch to consuming the OSC -tips job directly now, it merged yesterday... see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514847/ for an example of using it.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-10-27 05:33:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Dean, that's osc-functional-devstack-tips - but is this really the equivalent of legacy-cliff-tox-openstackclient-tip ?"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-10-27 14:16:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Andreas, thanks, no they are not equivalent, mostly due to unit tests (legacy) vs functional tests (v3 OSC -tips).  However after looking at the logs of the converted test, the legacy job is not actually testing much useful to us as it only installs python-openstackclient from master, not osc-lib or os-client-config, which the OSC job does.

So OK, lets' merge this as it is a 1-to-1 of the current state, but the current state needs to be fixed.  I'll add a -tips unit test job to OSC that covers all 4 interesting repos for that scenario and we can use that here, I'd argue that the -tips functional tests are also useful here too...and honestly what I am more interested in using to look for problems as unit tests tent to mock things out."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-10-27 14:27:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

A follow-up to add osc's functional-tpis is in https://review.openstack.org/515725"}, {'account_id': 22582, 'date': '2017-11-14 08:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
cap cmd2 also for python3

With python 3.6.6 osc is not able to work in an interactive mode 
(unrecognized argument). This can be reproduced by installing osc into 
the virtualenv created with python 3.6.6, 3.5.5, 3.4.8. Manual 
downgrading of cmd2 to 0.8.8 helps

Change-Id: I3bde60d16f92d6805ff5f6c1eee88bb3e474a07a

commit_message:
Fix ostestr invocation

More-recent versions of stestr are rather picky about wanting an integer
for concurrency [1], but ostestr prior to [2] defaults it to None. As a
result, all our func tests would fail with:

   TypeError: int() argument must be a string or a number, not 'NoneType'

Also, move the rolling upgrade job to non-voting since it's going to
pull in the old version but try to run with new deps.

[1] https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/c93bc81
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651275/

Change-Id: Icba6c46bcff0e0516107e0f6742d32c92488ae20

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-30 08:27:26.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Avoid using os-brick encryptors when device_path isn't provided

When disconnecting an encrypted volume the Libvirt driver uses the
presence of a Libvirt secret associated with the volume to determine if
the new style native QEMU LUKS decryption or original decryption method
using os-brick encrytors is used.

While this works well in most deployments some issues have been observed
in Kolla based environments where the Libvirt secrets are not fully
persisted between host reboots or container upgrades. This can lead to
_detach_encryptor attempting to build an encryptor which will fail if
the associated connection_info for the volume does not contain a
device_path, such as in the case for encrypted rbd volumes.

This change adds a simple conditional to _detach_encryptor to ensure we
return when device_path is not present in connection_info and native
QEMU LUKS decryption is available. This handles the specific use
case where we are certain that the encrypted volume was never decrypted
using the os-brick encryptors, as these require a local block device on
the compute host and have thus never supported rbd.

It is still safe to build an encryptor and call detach_volume when a
device_path is present however as change I9f52f89b8466d036 made such
calls idempotent within os-brick.

Change-Id: Id670f13a7f197e71c77dc91276fc2fba2fc5f314
Closes-bug: #1821696
(cherry picked from commit 56ca4d32ddf944b541b8a6c46f07275e7d8472bc)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Avoid using os-brick encryptors when device_path isn't provided

When disconnecting an encrypted volume the Libvirt driver uses the
presence of a Libvirt secret associated with the volume to determine if
the new style native QEMU LUKS decryption or original decryption method
using os-brick encrytors is used.

While this works well in most deployments some issues have been observed
in Kolla based environments where the Libvirt secrets are not fully
persisted between host reboots or container upgrades. This can lead to
_detach_encryptor attempting to build an encryptor which will fail if
the associated connection_info for the volume does not contain a
device_path, such as in the case for encrypted rbd volumes.

This change adds a simple conditional to _detach_encryptor to ensure we
return when device_path is not present in connection_info and native
QEMU LUKS decryption is available. This handles the specific use
case where we are certain that the encrypted volume was never decrypted
using the os-brick encryptors, as these require a local block device on
the compute host and have thus never supported rbd.

It is still safe to build an encryptor and call detach_volume when a
device_path is present however as change I9f52f89b8466d036 made such
calls idempotent within os-brick.

Change-Id: Id670f13a7f197e71c77dc91276fc2fba2fc5f314
Closes-bug: #1821696
(cherry picked from commit 56ca4d32ddf944b541b8a6c46f07275e7d8472bc)

[{'created': '2019-05-03 21:10:42.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Stop ignoring unknown libvirtError exceptions during volume attach

Id346bce6e47431988cce7001abcf29a9faf2936a attempted to introduce a
simple breadcrumb in the logs to highlight a known Libvirt issue.
Unfortunately this change resulted in libvirtError exceptions that
didn't match the known issue being silently ignored.

This change corrects this by using excutils.save_and_reraise_exception
to ensure all libvirtError exceptions are logged and raised regardless
of being linked to the known issue.

Change-Id: Ib440f4f2e484312af5f393722363846f6c95b760
Closes-Bug: #1825882
(cherry picked from commit bc57ae50734fa6a70115b6369e867079fb5eb4b8)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Stop ignoring unknown libvirtError exceptions during volume attach

Id346bce6e47431988cce7001abcf29a9faf2936a attempted to introduce a
simple breadcrumb in the logs to highlight a known Libvirt issue.
Unfortunately this change resulted in libvirtError exceptions that
didn't match the known issue being silently ignored.

This change corrects this by using excutils.save_and_reraise_exception
to ensure all libvirtError exceptions are logged and raised regardless
of being linked to the known issue.

Change-Id: Ib440f4f2e484312af5f393722363846f6c95b760
Closes-Bug: #1825882
(cherry picked from commit bc57ae50734fa6a70115b6369e867079fb5eb4b8)

[{'created': '2019-04-23 07:50:24.000000000', 'message': "Retry to declare a queue after internal error

Without this commit, the client can lose the messages, because the
client does not handler the 'AMQP internal error 541',
read here [2] for details.
The fix retries to create the queue after a delay.
When the virtual-host is ready the declare does not fail.
This is a rare condiction, please read the bug [1] for details.

Closes-Bug: #1822778

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778
[2] https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html

Change-Id: I7ab1f9d21ebb807285bf1422bc14cc6e07dcd32a
(cherry picked from commit 4d2787227b00b973973554f7387e621d2664c0d8)
"}]
commit_message:
Retry to declare a queue after internal error

Without this commit, the client can lose the messages, because the
client does not handler the 'AMQP internal error 541',
read here [2] for details.
The fix retries to create the queue after a delay.
When the virtual-host is ready the declare does not fail.
This is a rare condiction, please read the bug [1] for details.

Closes-Bug: #1822778

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778
[2] https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html

Change-Id: I7ab1f9d21ebb807285bf1422bc14cc6e07dcd32a
(cherry picked from commit 4d2787227b00b973973554f7387e621d2664c0d8)

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

commit_message:
Add app-credentials-specific policy rules

In order to have Create and Delete buttons for application credentials
in non-admin projects we need to add the respective policy.json rules.

The dashboard pane for application credentials was added in Rocky.

Change-Id: I42d4772ebe185c35cc5e81c36ebdb3f6f6c169c4
Closes-Bug: #1827107

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-25 20:26:53.000000000', 'message': "mistral: configure heartbeat parameters to avoid action timeout

This patch configures and increases the defaults heartbeat parameters in
Mistral so we don't hit timeouts when an action in a workflow takes
times to reply back in Mistral, when deploying an Overcloud.

Parameters added:

  MistralMaxMissedHeartbeats:
    type: number
    default: 15
    description: >
        The maximum amount of missed heartbeats to be allowed.
        If set to 0 then this feature is disabled. See check_interval for more
        details.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }
  MistralCheckInterval:
    type: number
    default: 20
    description: >
        How often (in seconds) action executions are checked.
        For example when check_interval is 10, check action
        executions every 10 seconds. When the checker runs it will
        transit all running action executions to error if the last
        heartbeat received is older than 10 * max_missed_heartbeats
        seconds. If set to 0 then this feature is disabled.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }
  MistralFirstHeartbeatTimeout:
    type: number
    default: 3600
    description: >
        The first heartbeat is handled differently, to provide a
        grace period in case there is no available executor to handle
        the action execution. For example when
        first_heartbeat_timeout = 3600, wait 3600 seconds before
        closing the action executions that never received a heartbeat.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }

Configuration applied to Undercloud:
Maximum missed heartbeats: 30 seconds
Time between interval checks: 40 seconds
First Heartbeat timeout after 7200 seconds

Depends-On: I7a2313bed58485e077ae210d222902f4f997f0f0
Change-Id: Id8663e76b61c9e09547c228da226b706383a3e20
Closes-Bug: #1821611

        For example when check_interval is 10, check action
        executions every 10 seconds. When the checker runs it will
        transit all running action executions to error if the last
        heartbeat received is older than 10 * max_missed_heartbeats
        seconds. If set to 0 then this feature is disabled.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }
  MistralFirstHeartbeatTimeout:
    type: number
    default: 3600
    description: >
        The first heartbeat is handled differently, to provide a
        grace period in case there is no available executor to handle
        the action execution. For example when
        first_heartbeat_timeout = 3600, wait 3600 seconds before
        closing the action executions that never received a heartbeat.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }

Configuration applied to Undercloud:
Maximum missed heartbeats: 30 seconds
Time between interval checks: 40 seconds
First Heartbeat timeout after 7200 seconds

Depends-On: I7a2313bed58485e077ae210d222902f4f997f0f0

commit_message:
mistral: configure heartbeat parameters to avoid action timeout

This patch configures and increases the defaults heartbeat parameters in
Mistral so we don't hit timeouts when an action in a workflow takes
times to reply back in Mistral, when deploying an Overcloud.

Parameters added:

  MistralMaxMissedHeartbeats:
    type: number
    default: 15
    description: >
        The maximum amount of missed heartbeats to be allowed.
        If set to 0 then this feature is disabled. See check_interval for more
        details.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }
  MistralCheckInterval:
    type: number
    default: 20
    description: >
        How often (in seconds) action executions are checked.
        For example when check_interval is 10, check action
        executions every 10 seconds. When the checker runs it will
        transit all running action executions to error if the last
        heartbeat received is older than 10 * max_missed_heartbeats
        seconds. If set to 0 then this feature is disabled.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }
  MistralFirstHeartbeatTimeout:
    type: number
    default: 3600
    description: >
        The first heartbeat is handled differently, to provide a
        grace period in case there is no available executor to handle
        the action execution. For example when
        first_heartbeat_timeout = 3600, wait 3600 seconds before
        closing the action executions that never received a heartbeat.
    constraints:
      - range: { min: 0 }

Configuration applied to Undercloud:
Maximum missed heartbeats: 30 seconds
Time between interval checks: 40 seconds
First Heartbeat timeout after 7200 seconds

Depends-On: I7a2313bed58485e077ae210d222902f4f997f0f0
Change-Id: Id8663e76b61c9e09547c228da226b706383a3e20
Closes-Bug: #1821611

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I32190b32bb53dd070ef85f68ffcfb7e43c403b4f

commit_message:
Add a Quick Start tutorial

As a user completely new to oslo_config (well, I had only experienced it
in the already-implemented context of the nova project), I would like to
have had a reference document that provided a step-by-step guide to
writing a simple test script I could use to noodle around.  It might
have gone something like this.

Change-Id: I02ff56f47ac8b93e0ee37eb55b53552059e4da27

There is one problem with this patch: when we return the available resources in nova.virt.vmwareapi.host, we always need to select the datastore with the largest freespace and report this to the scheduler'}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2017-10-18 08:01:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Thanks for the review.

I don't understand your comment though. Could you explain it a little further?"}, {'account_id': 9172, 'date': '2017-10-18 08:08:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

In host.py we use ds_util.get_datastore to get the free disk space which we report to the scheduler. We always want to report the largest free space to scheduler because otherwise booting instances will fail even if we have enough space. It's OK to have different strategies to select the most favorable datastore when more than one is available, but it's not OK to report less free space than we have."}, {'account_id': 6125, 'date': '2017-11-25 05:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

zvm:recheck'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2017-11-25 06:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-9583 : SUCCESS in 59m 14s'}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2017-12-01 18:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> In host.py we use ds_util.get_datastore to get the free disk space
 > which we report to the scheduler. We always want to report the
 > largest free space to scheduler because otherwise booting instances
 > will fail even if we have enough space. It's OK to have different
 > strategies to select the most favorable datastore when more than
 > one is available, but it's not OK to report less free space than we
 > have.

You are right. The question is how to solve that issue. We could add a parameter to get_datastore and _select_datastore functions to ignore the allocation_type from the config and always return the datastore with most free space.

Or we could add a parameter to explicitly tell the get_datastore and _select_datastore function which allocation_type to use and as a default define "useAllocationTypeFromConfig" or something like that.

The most clean solution would be not to use get_datastore for two purposes. At the moment it is used a) to get the datastore with most space so we can report that back to the scheduler and b) to get the datastore which fits best. By now both is accidently the same. ;) But since we want to change that, we should define exactly which of the two purposes the function is going to serve. Or define that it is used to do both tasks, because they are very similar. That would be the "pass some parameter to distinguish"-solution from above.

Please let me know what you think about this.'}, {'account_id': 9171, 'date': '2017-12-01 18:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9172, 'date': '2017-12-04 08:58:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

@David With the get_inventory method (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506175/), this is no longer a problem. We can return the aggregated free space from all datastores and the maximum free space available on a single datastore.
So I suggest to rebase this patch on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506175'}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2017-12-04 09:47:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> @David With the get_inventory method (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506175/),
 > this is no longer a problem. We can return the aggregated free
 > space from all datastores and the maximum free space available on a
 > single datastore.
 > So I suggest to rebase this patch on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506175

I will keep an eye on that patch. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 9171, 'date': '2017-12-05 07:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

Please see my last comment.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-04 13:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-25 14:03:05.000000000', 'message': "Choose VMware datastore by the least provisioned space

At the moment the _select_datastore method in the VMware driver chooses
the in dependence of the free space. The datastore with the most free
space will be chosen for a new instance. But some users may want to
place new instances on the datastore with the less provisioned space and
not the one with the most free space.

This feature introduces a new configuration parameter
'datastore_allocation_type'. When datastore_allocation_type is set to
'provisionedSpace' then the datastore with the lowest value for
provisionedSpace will be chosen. If set to 'freeSpace', the datastore
with the most free space will be chosen for a new instance.

Change-Id: Ibdcfd81554e47f2cb24f74d6cd1e48f2d9df9cc9
Closes-Bug: #1643569
"}, {'created': '2016-11-30 07:59:37.000000000', 'message': "Choose VMware datastore by the least provisioned space

At the moment the _select_datastore method in the VMware driver chooses
the in dependence of the free space. The datastore with the most free
space will be chosen for a new instance. But some users may want to
place new instances on the datastore with the less provisioned space or
most connected hosts.

commit_message:
Choose VMware datastore by the least provisioned space

At the moment the _select_datastore method in the VMware driver chooses
depending on the free space. The datastore with the most free
space will be chosen for a new instance. But some users may want to
place new instances on the datastore with the less provisioned space or
most connected hosts.

This patch introduces a new configuration parameter
'datastore_allocation_type'. When datastore_allocation_type is set to
'provisionedSpace' then the datastore with the lowest value for
provisionedSpace will be chosen. If set to 'freeSpace', the datastore
with the most free space will be chosen for a new instance. When
choosing 'mostConnectedHosts', prefer the one with more connected hosts.

Change-Id: Ibdcfd81554e47f2cb24f74d6cd1e48f2d9df9cc9
Closes-Bug: #1643569

subject: Use oslo_rootwrap subprocess module in order to gain proper eventlet awareness
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-04 02:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-05-04 03:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-04 02:58:28.000000000', 'message': 'Use oslo_rootwrap subprocess module in order to gain proper eventlet awareness

Via https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/commit/31cfdbd4076bb6556cf9612171ba43fa44475d71
oslo.rootwrap gained support eventlet when using subprocess. By moving
to oslo_rootwrap.subprocess we make sure that with python3 the
subprocess calls use eventlet.green.subprocess if eventlet is used.
This worked on python2 because (from above commit):
"""
On Python 2, it "works" to use directly subprocess: subprocess.Popen
calls os.pipe() and os.fdopen(fd) which are both monkey-patched. On
Python 3, it doesn't work because subprocess uses os.pipe() and
io.open(fd), and the io module is *not* monkey-patched at all.
"""

By applying this change what happens is that the heartbeat thread is
able to be scheduled every 15seconds by default. Without this patch
what we have been observing with python3 is that while running ansible
mistral would constantly log error messages like the following:
2019-05-02 19:14:36.702 8 WARNING oslo.messaging._drivers.impl_rabbit [-] Unexpected error during heartbeart thread processing, retrying...: amqp.exceptions.ConnectionForced: Too many heartbeats missed

With this change we could not reproduce this issue during a deployment
and no missed heartbeat messages were observed during the deploy.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1826281

Change-Id: Id22b1465d6d2424d90781983b970aba4545feb8a
(cherry picked from commit 2e54cff0db213494d07c72ce0f36d60831d2e84d)
'}]
commit_message:
Use oslo_rootwrap subprocess module in order to gain proper eventlet awareness

Via https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/commit/31cfdbd4076bb6556cf9612171ba43fa44475d71
oslo.rootwrap gained support eventlet when using subprocess. By moving
to oslo_rootwrap.subprocess we make sure that with python3 the
subprocess calls use eventlet.green.subprocess if eventlet is used.
This worked on python2 because (from above commit):
"""
On Python 2, it "works" to use directly subprocess: subprocess.Popen
calls os.pipe() and os.fdopen(fd) which are both monkey-patched. On
Python 3, it doesn't work because subprocess uses os.pipe() and
io.open(fd), and the io module is *not* monkey-patched at all.
"""

By applying this change what happens is that the heartbeat thread is
able to be scheduled every 15seconds by default. Without this patch
what we have been observing with python3 is that while running ansible
mistral would constantly log error messages like the following:
2019-05-02 19:14:36.702 8 WARNING oslo.messaging._drivers.impl_rabbit [-] Unexpected error during heartbeart thread processing, retrying...: amqp.exceptions.ConnectionForced: Too many heartbeats missed

With this change we could not reproduce this issue during a deployment
and no missed heartbeat messages were observed during the deploy.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: #1826281

Change-Id: Id22b1465d6d2424d90781983b970aba4545feb8a
(cherry picked from commit 2e54cff0db213494d07c72ce0f36d60831d2e84d)

commit_message:
Fix for werkzeug > 0.15

Werkzeug is pickier about how Content-Type is handled in general.
In this case we are now explicitly checking for either Content-Type
being '' or being non-existant in addition to Content-Type being set
to json for decoding the body.

Change-Id: Ia5a7750cff833aa90f7fc446f396c270343fc590

commit_message:
Move subnet postcommit out of transaction for bulk create

For auto-address IPv6 subnets postcommit has update port action
if the net already has ports. This results in
"cannot be called within a transaction" error for bulk IPv6 subnet
create.

Closes-Bug: #1822582
Change-Id: Ia32ec4c11c0793e7df07dcce19c122b3c7f865e1
(cherry picked from commit 14c76d31814b8e696349a1c00ba65ef2919b48af)

commit_message:
Correct discover_version response

The discover_version function was ignoring the max microversion
supported by the client.  This patch corrects its behavior to return
the most recent API version, if any, supported by both the client
and the server it is communicating with.

Closes-bug: #1826286
Change-Id: If22b72452065080b24cb1b899c5a5a88b809e986

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-09 20:55:27.000000000', 'message': "Use raw string for regex

Special characters in regular strings now cause DeprecationWarnings
starting with Python 3.6. This frequently happens with regex strings.

Oslo.log had one instance of a regex string containing '\' that would
cause deprecation warnings in logs. This switches that instance over to
be a raw string to avoid these warnings.

Change-Id: Ia5637f35315127c5cc46e01f5e38eccb094e772d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Use raw string for regex

Special characters in regular strings now cause DeprecationWarnings
starting with Python 3.6. This frequently happens with regex strings.

Oslo.log had one instance of a regex string containing '\' that would
cause deprecation warnings in logs. This switches that instance over to
be a raw string to avoid these warnings.

Change-Id: Ia5637f35315127c5cc46e01f5e38eccb094e772d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-06 17:11:09.000000000', 'message': "objects: avoid deepcopying models in test_db_obj

SQLAlchemy may asynchronously push models out of session cache in which
case we may receive DetachedInstanceError.

In the test case, instead of deepcopying models to compare, compare
each modified attribute independently.

This change also includes conversion from InstrumentedLists to regular
lists when converting model attributes to object fields. The fact that
we were returning InstrumentedLists was always an oversight but it
revealed itself after the modification of the test case that is the
core of this patch.

When converting object fields to db, convert Port's distributed_binding
None value to a empty list to reflect that the relationship of the Port
database model is a list. It was not an issue before the patch because
we were not comparing model attribute for equality but for in-equality
before, and so None was always != [].

Finally, this patch moves a bunch of TODOs to better reflect where they
belong to.

Closes-Bug: #1770452
Change-Id: I42cdf540129bd4470ec1a59345db9845a6198328
(cherry picked from commit 1a8a15f6309a56087702a0974041fa9850de4f62)

commit_message:
objects: avoid deepcopying models in test_db_obj

SQLAlchemy may asynchronously push models out of session cache in which
case we may receive DetachedInstanceError.

In the test case, instead of deepcopying models to compare, compare
each modified attribute independently.

This change also includes conversion from InstrumentedLists to regular
lists when converting model attributes to object fields. The fact that
we were returning InstrumentedLists was always an oversight but it
revealed itself after the modification of the test case that is the
core of this patch.

When converting object fields to db, convert Port's distributed_binding
None value to a empty list to reflect that the relationship of the Port
database model is a list. It was not an issue before the patch because
we were not comparing model attribute for equality but for in-equality
before, and so None was always != [].

Finally, this patch moves a bunch of TODOs to better reflect where they
belong to.

Closes-Bug: #1770452
Change-Id: I42cdf540129bd4470ec1a59345db9845a6198328
(cherry picked from commit 1a8a15f6309a56087702a0974041fa9850de4f62)

commit_message:
Get ports query: extract limit and use it only at the end.

_get_ports_query add filters after a get_collection. If limits are
passed to applied to the query, then no additional filter is allowed.
This patch extracts an eventual limit argument, to apply it only after
the additional filters.

Change-Id: I83394394860d10e27379efe0356d0fa9c567140e
Closes-Bug: #1826186
(cherry picked from commit cf8f3326be14d30456b20e4d1a55a36762daa550)

commit_message:
Get ports query: extract limit and use it only at the end.

_get_ports_query add filters after a get_collection. If limits are
passed to applied to the query, then no additional filter is allowed.
This patch extracts an eventual limit argument, to apply it only after
the additional filters.

Change-Id: I83394394860d10e27379efe0356d0fa9c567140e
Closes-Bug: #1826186
(cherry picked from commit cf8f3326be14d30456b20e4d1a55a36762daa550)

Hi Ben, Please see comments.

I think it is worth writing a very simple debug patch that invokes update_access in drivers twice and see what breaks, so we can be sure if there are backends that break when attempting to add the same rule twice. The API blocks this, but the way you are doing in ensure_share would end up doing that in the driver level.'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2018-03-01 16:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

2 hours isn't enough and on deployments where Ansible takes more than 2
hours it failed again with the same error reported in bug #1821611.

Increasing the timeout to 4 hours to follow the default timeout value in
overcloud deploy command.

Change-Id: I29e65bb828c9e66dca9a0f1206152c705f7beabf
Related-Bug: #1821611
"}, {'created': '2019-04-12 03:10:50.000000000', 'message': 'undercloud: increase MistralCheckInterval to 240s

We increased MistralFirstHeartBeatTimeout default to 7200 (2 hours), but
now we hit an issue with the second heartbeat which takes more than
30x40 seconds (20 minutes).

Increasing the timeout to 2 hours to follow the first heartbeat timeout value.

Change-Id: I29e65bb828c9e66dca9a0f1206152c705f7beabf
Related-Bug: #1821611
'}]
commit_message:
undercloud: increase MistralCheckInterval to 240s

We increased MistralFirstHeartBeatTimeout default to 7200 (2 hours), but
now we hit an issue with the second heartbeat which takes more than
30x40 seconds (20 minutes).

Increasing the timeout to 2 hours to follow the first heartbeat timeout value.

Change-Id: I29e65bb828c9e66dca9a0f1206152c705f7beabf
Related-Bug: #1821611

[{'created': '2019-01-15 18:23:03.000000000', 'message': "Update the hiera hook to work with Puppet5 and beyond.

Hiera in Puppet5 has a format that isn't compatible with Puppet4, we
have to change the file format so it works with recent versions of
Puppet.

This patch isn't backward compatible with old versions of Puppet. If you
run Puppet4, it'll likely break you.

Change-Id: I3c7df59e493f02fe2c5018a025b515c2b0f50860
"}]
commit_message:
Update the hiera hook to work with Puppet5 and beyond.

Hiera in Puppet5 has a format that isn't compatible with Puppet4, we
have to change the file format so it works with recent versions of
Puppet.

This patch isn't backward compatible with old versions of Puppet. If you
run Puppet4, it'll likely break you.

Change-Id: I3c7df59e493f02fe2c5018a025b515c2b0f50860

subject: Add option to toggle validation of signed image
messages: [{'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-04-03 16:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2019-05-03 22:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2019-05-03 22:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-03 16:36:21.000000000', 'message': "Add option to toggle validation of signed image

Without this patch, if the barbican tempest plugin is installed in an
environment running with `[glance]/verify_glance_signatures] set to
false in nova.conf, which is the default value, the test will fail.
Enabling glance signature verification unconditionally in order to
support this test is not realistic, as it then prevents users from
booting from unsigned images which may not always be desired. This patch
adds a configuration option to allow for disabling the
`test_signed_image_upload_boot_failure` test, so that we can still run
the majority of the plugin tests for a standard environment with default
nova configuration. The new option defaults to `True`, meaning assume
that nova's configuration has been overrridden to enforce image
verification, which allows the barbican CI to run as normal with no
configuration changes, but it allows operators to explicitly disable the
test as needed.

Change-Id: Ibb5c06ce2773e0ee13bda97717e8e18e77e0be7c
"}]
commit_message:
Add option to toggle validation of signed image

Without this patch, if the barbican tempest plugin is installed in an
environment running with `[glance]/verify_glance_signatures] set to
false in nova.conf, which is the default value, the test will fail.
Enabling glance signature verification unconditionally in order to
support this test is not realistic, as it then prevents users from
booting from unsigned images which may not always be desired. This patch
adds a configuration option to allow for disabling the
`test_signed_image_upload_boot_failure` test, so that we can still run
the majority of the plugin tests for a standard environment with default
nova configuration. The new option defaults to `True`, meaning assume
that nova's configuration has been overrridden to enforce image
verification, which allows the barbican CI to run as normal with no
configuration changes, but it allows operators to explicitly disable the
test as needed.

Change-Id: Ibb5c06ce2773e0ee13bda97717e8e18e77e0be7c
