We are not getting messageID and message if call gets successful execution for foreign drives. Also document suggests that only. We found the same in our previous investigation also.
I suggest Monica, you have already put ReturnValue=0 which is the only response we are getting in SUCCESS.
Please proceed with other comments to add check for ERROR scenarios otherwise logic looks good. Also try to make one return statement as Richard suggested.'}, {'account_id': 8580, 'date': '2019-04-28 09:54:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23847, 'date': '2019-04-28 23:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

This change has significant issues which need to be resolved before it can be merged.

It causes the clear_foreign_config() method to work correctly only if no foreign drive was detected.

When foreign drives are detected and successfully cleared, it raises an AttributeError exception.

And when the iDRAC returns errors other than STOR018 -- "No foreign drives detected", it hides/masks them and returns success, as if foreign drives were detected and cleared.'}, {'account_id': 8580, 'date': '2019-04-29 03:59:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Sure Richard. I am taking this item on my top priority to get it resolved as per your suggestions with proper testing.
I and Monica have done investigation over the weekend and I am sure we are able to implement all the scenarios today only.
Thanks for your fruitful reviews.'}, {'account_id': 29863, 'date': '2019-04-29 04:26:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

commit_message:
clear_foreign_config() succeeds if no foreign disk

When clear_foreign_config() does not detect a foreign disk, instead
of failing and raising an exception, it succeeds and returns a value
which informs the caller nothing further needs to be done.

Change-Id: I4cea95659db11747b1c8708e1dbe7cac53c0eaf9

commit_message:
Notify #openstack-ptg IRC channel on ptgbot dev activity

Anyone in #openstack-ptg is likely to be using ptgbot, so it'll
probably help if they are aware of ongoing bugfixes / enhancements
etc. to the bot.  Bot development is slow paced enough that this
is unlikely to cause spam issues :-)

Change-Id: I91d51259c6faf84b94820f11120f28f34df1552b

breaks installation with setup.py.

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ib68a1cb57957e5705dcdf1ee0f46cf9359a6bf47

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 13:48:03.000000000', 'message': 'Increment versioning with pbr instruction

With moving away from required milestone releases, the version numbers
calculated by PBR on the master branch will not work for those testing
upgrades from the last stable release. More details can be found in the
mailing list post here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135706.html

This is an empty commit that will cause PBR to increment its calculated
version to get around this.

PBR will see the following which will cause it to increment the version:

Sem-Ver: feature

Please merge this patch as soon as possible to support those testing
upgrades.

Change-Id: Ieb5652e4bf238c9787ac3669b92b20333add6b4e
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Increment versioning with pbr instruction

With moving away from required milestone releases, the version numbers
calculated by PBR on the master branch will not work for those testing
upgrades from the last stable release. More details can be found in the
mailing list post here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135706.html

This is an empty commit that will cause PBR to increment its calculated
version to get around this.

PBR will see the following which will cause it to increment the version:

Sem-Ver: feature

Please merge this patch as soon as possible to support those testing
upgrades.

Change-Id: Ieb5652e4bf238c9787ac3669b92b20333add6b4e
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-10-16 18:11:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-10-23 21:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2018-10-23 22:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-10-24 02:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

At this point I think this is a regression.  We added ceilometer to g-r (and u-c) so projects can rely on it like other libraries[1].  Adding this to the blacklist will just break those projects later.

I suggest that deployment tools that are doing so from source (kolla) need to accommodate this there.

[1] I knwo that a service isn't a library but that's the way it's been written and used."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-31 13:13:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can this be abandoned now?'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:05:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

it's still one of the 'valid' solutions, but not the optimal one, I'll -W for now

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/requirements-libs"}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2019-03-08 22:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

iirc, isn't edit-constraints suposed to be used on constraints before installing anything that's constrained from source?  The same problem described in the story would hit all the oslo stuff too."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

going to abandon this as projects are going to start switching to cycle-with-intermediary (or force users to use foo-lib)'}]

Add ceilometer to blacklist.txt

used as libs projects (neutron and horizon).

Task: 26739

commit_message:
Add HTTP image download for virtual media emulation

Image download is implemented in the Manager driver for Virtual
Media boot feature to function.

Image download is local to the emulator machine, meaning that
for downloaded image to be accessible the hypervisor must be
running on the same machine with the emulator.

Change-Id: If66e0857218b68e82a9cab4c9a76a709ff360297
Story: 2005149
Task: 29858

messages: [{'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:24:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:25:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:\n\nThe fact that the bot hasn't crashed yet speaks well of the OpenStack dev community's understanding of regexps ;-)"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:26:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-02 17:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-02 17:24:14.000000000', 'message': 'Check that subscription regexen compile before accepting them

Previously we blindly accepted any string as a regex, but then
it could fail to compile at search-time when a track topic got
updated, which would cause the bot to crash.

So do a precautionary compile of the regex in order to ensure
we only accept valid regexen.

Change-Id: Id347b88adfc7150ff26550cf9170071e7ac33227
'}]
commit_message:
Check that subscription regexen compile before accepting them

Previously we blindly accepted any string as a regex, but then
it could fail to compile at search-time when a track topic got
updated, which would cause the bot to crash.

So do a precautionary compile of the regex in order to ensure
we only accept valid regexen.

Change-Id: Id347b88adfc7150ff26550cf9170071e7ac33227

Add a new configuration option for setting the Pure host personality.
It determines how the Purity system tunes the protocol used between
the array and the initiator. To ensure the array works optimally with
the host, set the personality to the name of the host operating or
virtual memory system. Valid values are aix, esxi, hitachi-vsp, hpux,
oracle-vm-server, solaris, and vms. If your system is not listed as
one of the valid host personalities, do not set the option. By
default, the host personality is not set.

commit_message:
Allow setting Pure host personality

Add a new configuration option for setting the Pure host personality.
It determines how the Purity system tunes the protocol used between
the array and the initiator. To ensure the array works optimally with
the host, set the personality to the name of the host operating or
virtual memory system. Valid values are aix, esxi, hitachi-vsp, hpux,
oracle-vm-server, solaris, and vms. If your system is not listed as
one of the valid host personalities, do not set the option. By
default, the host personality is not set.

Change-Id: I5065ccbed27c5b7c3b32ae8eda221c151a8bbaa9

commit_message:
Use 'DEFAULT_VALIDATIONS_BASEDIR' variable from constants.py

Instead of using 'TRIPLEO_VALIDATIONS' as an hardcoded variable, this
patch will use 'DEFAULT_VALIDATIONS_BASEDIR' variable coming from
constants.py.

Change-Id: I5c08ca0bfb9923f7b6834f0d14464c60320f6e6f
Implements: blueprint inflight-validations
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update unbook documentation

Not all slots can be unbooked with the ~unbook command. Those
slots that have been pre-scheduled require changes to the
puppet-ptgbot repo to unbook slots.

Change-Id: I1b7aad1b539a2bcff067206b4885e690f7018f32

[{'created': '2019-04-19 12:51:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-04-19 14:34:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command. It also removes an
useless line in the sudoers file.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-04-26 15:51:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command. It also removes an
useless line in the sudoers file.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command. It also removes an
useless line in the sudoers file.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

clarify.

commit_message:
Add writable Virtual Media resource mocks

This change implements Insert/Eject actions against the VirtualMedia
resource. Although all changes are just volatile mocks - virtual media
emulation is not yet backed by anything.

The upcoming patches will convey virtual media calls to systems
drivers (e.g. libvirt and/or nova) to make VMs bootable from the
inserted images.

Change-Id: I9b6508377891a3fd67f23fd0973c29f17de08ee1

commit_message:
Add read-only Virtual Media support

This patch introduces VirtualMedia resource to the Manager
resource in read-only mode. Meaning that virtual media devices
can be configured for emulation, but can't be manipulated yet.

The follow up patches will bring media insert and eject
actions.

Change-Id: I16f1e07817ef9614c3461bf3ab47d2e8fa82b573

commit_message:
Remove deprecated 'default_flavor' config option

The deprecated 'default_flavor' option has been removed.
The following methods in nova/compute/flavors.py
have been removed because they are only used in unit tests.

* get_default_flavor
* get_flavor_by_name

Change-Id: If1e461da382f707be2b5ba89f74f77269f0909dd

However, nothing else is necessary here, fwict"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-04-04 22:19:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Kibana: Add security context for pod/container

This adds a security context to the kibana chart, which
changes the pod's user from root to the nobody user instead

This also adds the container security context to set
allowPrivilegeEscalation to false and readOnlyRootFilesystem to true

Change-Id: I3b8d0833435c6c9b9bb249de8e5ce251a54a3e96

commit_message:
Bug Fix: Parses notifier configuration options

Successfully parses configuration options for enabled notifiers.
IMPORTANT: This requires the built-in notifiers be "enabled"
in the configuration.

This patch is compliant with `https://review.openstack.org/#/c/435136/`
that in summary makes every notifier pluggable as apposed distinguished
built-in and pluggable notifiers.

Change-Id: I818212344268de5e90e72c5493a8632476ba254b
Story: #2003794
Task: #26507

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: If536a6a251145a3923dfa692b3477d23797bf132

nodes before they get deleted from the stack.

commit_message:
scale-down: run ansible_scale_down workflow before node_delete

With the new workflow, ansible_scale_down, we can now tear down the
nodes before they get deleted from the stack.

blueprint scale-down-tasks
Change-Id: I9982f3854604497c804d7875b926f14e1060b788

commit_message:
Update volume-backed comment in _validate_flavor_image_nostatus

This clarifies and updates the big comment in the volume-backed
case in the _validate_flavor_image_nostatus method since the
method is called by more than just server create. The method is
definitely tightly coupled with what calls it, so this tries to
clarify that.

Change-Id: I4b56458767e2712ad812db3b0901807d2c4aa848

commit_message:
Drop py35 jobs

Python 3.5 was the target runtime for the Rocky release. The current
target py3 runtime for Stein is Python 3.6, so there is no reason to
keep testing against the older version.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html#python-runtime-for-stein

Change-Id: Id6d0c53becf09741689dee0d7b30e5c397a63227

commit_message:
Drop py35 jobs

Python 3.5 was the target runtime for the Rocky release. The current
target py3 runtime for Stein is Python 3.6, so there is no reason to
keep testing against the older version.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html#python-runtime-for-stein

Change-Id: I136f092985be2d05ce933230add5f78469234b14

commit_message:
Update worklist information for contributors

When the worklists were first created, cdent was unaware of
how to make the worklists filter by story state so a tag of
'fixed' was being used to indicate "done".

This change updates the docs to reflect new awareness. The
associated worklists have already been updated.

Change-Id: I445b67ff85be7979805d72ac953f0853ee738f46

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to transition plan [1],
we should have py36 testenv ready for it.

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition

Change-Id: I3b15beb017bfd94aa1753be8efcd267df62a57c9

commit_message:
Use entire tenant id as scope

Previously, we create scope which is used for isolation in gateway,
like docker isolation, from fist 13 characters of tenant id, but
it is not consistent with ansible scripts, which use whole tenent id
as scope name.

This patch makes storlet middleware pass entire tenant id to
gateway as its scope, so that we can also prevent possible
conflicaiton between gateway scopes, caused by reduced characters.

Change-Id: Ic041d34d570ee61aae90f64319d74f58bcb58c2b

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-19 02:40:03.000000000', 'message': '[WIP]Less neutron call in build_nw_info

This patch want to less the neutron call when build_nw_info in sync
instance cache periodly or other operations. We can get all the ports info
from an instance, and get all related resources info, such as floatingip,
network, subnet. Then we can construct our models in Nova.

Change-Id: I8591094e141578775729fee35542702a2bbc5122
'}]
commit_message:
[WIP]Less neutron call in build_nw_info

This patch want to less the neutron call when build_nw_info in sync
instance cache periodly or other operations. We can get all the ports info
from an instance, and get all related resources info, such as floatingip,
network, subnet. Then we can construct our models in Nova.

Change-Id: I8591094e141578775729fee35542702a2bbc5122

commit_message:
Add ServiceNetMap to global_vars

This adds the ServiceNetMap value to global_vars for config-download.
This will make the value consumable from ansible tasks when running
config-download.

Additional values can be added in a similar fashion in the future to
allow for less hardcoded data coming out of Heat, and instead using
jinja expressions to consume data from Ansible variables when
config-download runs.

Change-Id: I8c442caac140f1c96123c1be47e858949419fd8f

[{'created': '2019-04-24 18:10:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add Keystone admin/public to enabled services list

These services need to be added to the ServiceNames resources list of
enabled services per role if we want groupings for them to be created in
the ansible inventory.

This same logic already exists in network/ports/net_ip_list_map.j2.yaml,
where the hieradata for <service>_node_[names,ips] are created. We also
need these service groupings to exist in the ansible inventory if we
want to make this hieradata generic instead of hardcoded coming out of
the heat templates.

Change-Id: Ie4c221a850a9018b4eb62bfd3d54ac22395b7a9c
'}]
commit_message:
Add Keystone admin/public to enabled services list

These services need to be added to the ServiceNames resources list of
enabled services per role if we want groupings for them to be created in
the ansible inventory.

This same logic already exists in network/ports/net_ip_list_map.j2.yaml,
where the hieradata for <service>_node_[names,ips] are created. We also
need these service groupings to exist in the ansible inventory if we
want to make this hieradata generic instead of hardcoded coming out of
the heat templates.

Change-Id: Ie4c221a850a9018b4eb62bfd3d54ac22395b7a9c

[{'account_id': 26575, 'date': '2019-04-23 08:15:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-04-23 08:15:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26575, 'date': '2019-04-24 08:59:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-24 09:30:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13637, 'date': '2019-04-24 10:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-04-24 20:07:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I think it's fine to add this even if the spec you cite in the bug hasn't been implemented yet -- it's a legitimate hypervisor identifier."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-04-24 20:13:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

In addition to the two inline comments above, it looks like you're proposing the first metadefs change for Train, so you have the honor of beginning the Train metadefs release note.  You can use releasenotes/notes/rocky-metadefs-changes-cb00c006ff51b541.yaml as a model."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-24 20:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 13637, 'date': '2019-04-25 00:18:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 26575, 'date': '2019-04-26 07:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26575, 'date': '2019-04-26 07:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Added powervm as hypervisor type for image metadata prefiltering.

"powervm" as hypervisor type is required for image metadata
prefiltering in glance.

Closes-Bug: #1826136

Change-Id: I7afd43c2e0581d30a78d5ed4e30f8eb2af1cf444

commit_message:
Fix service_uuid migration for volumes with no host

For volumes that have no host assigned, this
migration will fail.  Skip those volumes, as they
don't need to be updated.

Closes-Bug: #1821207
Change-Id: I08487575e52c5cfd5a268a23d97b6bd931aeaa45

[{'created': '2019-04-26 12:20:48.000000000', 'message': 'Remove obsolete get_backup_driver functions

With [1], backup driver modules are no longer expected to provide a
get_backup_driver function. This patch removes them all, as the
backup manager no longer calls them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/595372

Change-Id: Ic2562b98c00cbf567503edf275b6d7d97820058c
'}]
commit_message:
Remove obsolete get_backup_driver functions

With [1], backup driver modules are no longer expected to provide a
get_backup_driver function. This patch removes them all, as the
backup manager no longer calls them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/595372

Change-Id: Ic2562b98c00cbf567503edf275b6d7d97820058c

messages:
[{'account_id': 6541, 'date': '2019-02-21 18:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-02-21 18:25:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-02-21 22:57:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6541, 'date': '2019-02-22 07:26:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-02-22 10:26:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for working on this Kamil.

I'm wondering about system testing.  I noticed that there is a Tempest test that sets allowed_address_pairs, and I've created https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638621/ to see what happens when we run that test.  But I think what we really need is to test connecting to a VM using its new allowed_address_pair IP, and I don't believe that test covers that."}, {'account_id': 6541, 'date': '2019-02-22 13:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6541, 'date': '2019-02-22 14:07:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> Thanks for working on this Kamil.
 > 
 > I'm wondering about system testing.  I noticed that there is a
 > Tempest test that sets allowed_address_pairs, and I've created
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638621/ to see what happens when
 > we run that test.  But I think what we really need is to test
 > connecting to a VM using its new allowed_address_pair IP, and I
 > don't believe that test covers that.

I'm testing it on my own openstack instance, but it is still just manual testing, so tempest testing would be certainly helpful. For example, today I found that first implementation brokes dhcp agent. I made a fix, but I'm not sure it is right way to do it."}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-03-01 09:37:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Kamil, how is your own system testing going now? Will you let me know explicitly when you think this change could be good to go?'}, {'account_id': 6541, 'date': '2019-03-01 10:09:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Kamil, how is your own system testing going now? Will you let me
 > know explicitly when you think this change could be good to go?

From my point of view, it is working as expected in my environment. Each IP in allowed-address-pair field gets new route, but dhcp record is made only for main fixed IP address. What about tempest testing you mentioned? Shouldn't we wait till it'll pass successfully?"}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-04-11 10:56:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Many thanks Kamil, I'll allow this to merge now because you say it works for you, and I believe it cannot harm networking-calico's existing function.

I will just note one detailed technical point here.  This change adds a new key, 'allowedIps', to the JSON data that networking-calico stores in etcd for a WorkloadEndpoint, but 'allowedIps' is not part of the official WorkloadEndpoint definition at https://github.com/projectcalico/libcalico-go/blob/master/lib/apis/v3/workloadendpoint.go#L38.  Therefore this change relies on other Calico components (specifically libcalico-go and Felix) allowing unrecognised keys to be present in WorkloadEndpoint data - which, happily, they do.

There might be other ramifications of this, and if so we will have to come back and update this change accordingly.  But I can't think of any of those right now, so let's add this in."}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-04-11 12:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-04-30 16:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2019-05-01 23:05:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}]

More implementation details to come, but someone form the CLI/SDK work like Dean or Monty are also likely to be good sources of feedback as to if this sounds sane."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-25 14:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(10 comments)

I fully support this as a goal. I have some questions/comments about the implementation plan inline.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-25 14:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from new/deletion to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-02-25 22:40:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(10 comments)

Thanks for the comments Doug!

Essentially, this implementation is up for debate, but we needed a starting point, and this seemed like a way that could work, but I'm more than happy for better alternatives or adjustments.

We just can't spend forever arguing about it, so all I care about is settling on a solution we can all mostly agree on. :)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-26 00:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23924, 'date': '2019-02-26 09:35:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Solid work Adrian, think you have covered the use case really good. One thing that I know was discussed that I can't find here is "shared resources" like glance imaged for example; how those should be treaded? Force deleted, option flag or just fail if those exists? 

I'm happy to volunteer as one of the champions for this goal, which will be more focus on "project management" and making sure we are solving the use use case, less on code. I also think that adding a TC member as one of the champions is a good idea.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-26 21:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Functionality is all mostly the same, but less over-engineering needed to make all the pieces fit together."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-06 23:27:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/DEN-Train-PublicCloudWG-brainstorming"}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-07 14:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-11 20:10:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

Thanks Adrian for the effort, much appreciated. few comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-11 23:43:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

@Ghanshyam Mann

I'm reply here rather than inline about the API part.

 > having API per services to delete their all resources and having additional plugin is confusing and complex. after reading the above idea of doing it in sdks are good options.
 > 
 > Other point we need to think is do we need APIs to implement for this or a CLI/tool which does all these deletion work. I am on doing via CLI/Tool option. Implementing new APIs on each service side is not preferable for me because of below reason:
 > 
 >  - These are not the direct user interface. Those API are only mean to be used internally by deletion-tool or SDKs etc.
 > 
 >  - maintaining the API on the project side is costly especially when microversion is involved in implementation.
 > 
 > - This can lead to a security loophole of providing a REST interface to delete all resources of that service. though we can add rbac control on this but still a dangerous as user-facing interface.
 > 
 > Instead of API, a CLI/tool on service side which call the resource deletion should work perfectly here. and that CLI/tool can be consumed by top level library/SDKs etc.

Maintaining the APIs is no more costly than the library/tool. We still NEED a cli/tool, but once an API exists, the tool logic can potentially be simpler while some of the deletion happens server side.

The biggest benefit of an API, even if just an ability to do bulk deletion, is that it would improve the time taken to delete things. Right now any tool would have to go over every resource one by one and call a delete API for each. This is terrible design. The API support is needed to help make this better, or potentially in cases where it won't be broken by resource dependency, do some of the logic in the service.

As for security loopholes, that's a bad argument purely because scope and policy is a thing that exists and we can also make the APIs limited by default in certain ways. We're historically not THAT bad at policy and scope to the point that we're afraid of adding new APIs. If that's the case, then we have some serious problems.

If we write a standard, and each service implements the APIs in the same way, then that becomes MUCH simpler from both a user perspective and a maintainer perspective. It also means that other languages can write simpler libraries and tools compared to this goal which is python only.

Essentially, an API based solution is the future, and we will continue to push for it, but this library is a first step in that direction. After it exists and we know how the dependencies look, we can see what the service APIs may look like, and design them for Part Two."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-03-12 00:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-12 04:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-12 12:46:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-14 05:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-14 05:59:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok. Rewritten as additional features added to the SDK.

Now a single library with an established codebase, and potentially some existing devs who also would be interested in this goal.

Still will be a lot of custom logic and code that doesn't exist in the SDK at all, and we will still probably need further devs, but this is now squarely in OpenStackSDK land.


There are probably a lot of typos and some nonsense, so feedback is very appreciated and I'll reread it myself when I'm a little more sane and add some of my own comments."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-15 02:07:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I realise I forgot to add a note about why we aren't just reusing OSPURGE.

I'll add that as a note in a follow up revision once other comments exists, but the gist mostly is:
The SDK is actually a better place for it, and the approach we want to take probably a bit different. We can reuse parts of OSPURGE that may be useful, but overall this will probably be all new code, with influences from multiple sources and examples such as OSPURGE and various scripts written by cloud operators."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-15 10:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-03-15 12:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-20 19:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-20 21:07:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-20 21:11:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > @Ghanshyam Mann
 > 
 > I'm reply here rather than inline about the API part.
 > 
 > > having API per services to delete their all resources and having
 > additional plugin is confusing and complex. after reading the above
 > idea of doing it in sdks are good options.
 > >

 > this or a CLI/tool which does all these deletion work. I am on
 > doing via CLI/Tool option. Implementing new APIs on each service
 > side is not preferable for me because of below reason:
 > >
 > >  - These are not the direct user interface. Those API are only
 > mean to be used internally by deletion-tool or SDKs etc.
 > >
 > >  - maintaining the API on the project side is costly especially
 > when microversion is involved in implementation.
 > >

 > interface to delete all resources of that service. though we can
 > add rbac control on this but still a dangerous as user-facing

 > >

 > potentially be simpler while some of the deletion happens server
 > side.
 > 
 > The biggest benefit of an API, even if just an ability to do bulk
 > deletion, is that it would improve the time taken to delete things.
 > Right now any tool would have to go over every resource one by one
 > and call a delete API for each. This is terrible design. The API
 > support is needed to help make this better, or potentially in cases
 > where it won't be broken by resource dependency, do some of the
 > logic in the service.
 > 
 > As for security loopholes, that's a bad argument purely because
 > scope and policy is a thing that exists and we can also make the
 > APIs limited by default in certain ways. We're historically not
 > THAT bad at policy and scope to the point that we're afraid of
 > adding new APIs. If that's the case, then we have some serious

 > 
 > If we write a standard, and each service implements the APIs in the
 > same way, then that becomes MUCH simpler from both a user
 > perspective and a maintainer perspective. It also means that other
 > languages can write simpler libraries and tools compared to this
 > goal which is python only.
 > 
 > Essentially, an API based solution is the future, and we will
 > continue to push for it, but this library is a first step in that
 > direction. After it exists and we know how the dependencies look,
 > we can see what the service APIs may look like, and design them for
 > Part Two.

Well, i disgree on the point that APIs are not costly in term of maintenance. I feel, they are most difficult to maintain and keep as you cannot remove or change them without maintaining the backward incompatibility even that is buggy API. You can take nova example where we have lot of APIs around and cannot get rid of those for same reason.

But you made a good point of execution time with API vs other tooling. single API can save a time to execute the bulk deletions with simgle token and DB access. This is convincing me thinking towards API proposal. 

But as of now I am good with API as this is part-2 and we diascuss more on this during part-2 phase."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-20 22:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-21 13:48:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I said in an earlier review that I fully support this goal. That was based on my understanding of the discussion in Berlin, and over the course of subsequent reviews I have come to a different conclusion. I am still enthusiastic about having this *feature*, but I'm less sure about using the *goals process* to implement it.

My main concern is that it’s not clear why we need the entire community working on this. It involves minimal knowledge of the resources presented by each service and their relationships to update code in 1 library in a consistent way. It really feels like something 2-3 people could iterate on and build in a cycle or two. It seems that since we can’t muster a small group of contributors to do that work we're instead trying to structure it as a goal with the belief that doing so will somehow surface contributors. That feels like it isn't going to give us an ideal technical solution because there is no strong design leader, and like it's a bad precedent for us to use in terms of setting community goals because it turns a small project into a big one for the wrong reasons at a time when we need to be trying to find ways to turn big projects into small ones."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-03-22 05:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23924, 'date': '2019-03-22 07:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-25 11:30:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

-1 due to discussion points on Thursday. I'm sure we're not completely set on what is to happen here, but it's a notifier for myself and others in this case."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-03-25 22:38:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1 Workflow-1

The conclusion for the meeting we had last week mostly amounts to:
This goal doesn't fit unless we start doing the API work, and we aren't ready for the API work.

We will still need some feedback as we make the SDK part from a good chunk of people, but not a full goal level approach.

I'll write up an email to the mailing list, and start figuring out how to make this a nice and mostly smaller project in the SDK for handling project deletion logic.

Once we have that logic, we can look at what the API related changes need to be to make that logic faster/safer and do that a a full community wide goal."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-26 09:44:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> The conclusion for the meeting we had last week mostly amounts to:
 > This goal doesn't fit unless we start doing the API work, and we
 > aren't ready for the API work.
 > 
 > We will still need some feedback as we make the SDK part from a
 > good chunk of people, but not a full goal level approach.
 > 
 > I'll write up an email to the mailing list, and start figuring out
 > how to make this a nice and mostly smaller project in the SDK for
 > handling project deletion logic.
 > 
 > Once we have that logic, we can look at what the API related
 > changes need to be to make that logic faster/safer and do that a a
 > full community wide goal.

Great :) thanks for the summary Adrian. I'll watch out for the email!"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-05-01 21:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2019-05-01 21:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2019-05-01 22:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

It has been decided that this will not be done as a community goal, and rather just a small SDK focused project to create a maintainable and officially supported toolkit for deleting the project resources.

Once we know what the issues involved are from the SDK side, we can look at changes to the APIs (and propose those as a goal) to improve the performance and safety of project deletion.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-05-01 23:28:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Here's some discussion for this topic from summit https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/DEN-Deletion-of-resources"}]

commit_message:

In tempest, alias 'manager' has been moved to 'os_primary'
in version Pike, and it will be removed in version Queens.
This patch is to replace the usage of 'manager' with 'os_primary'.

For other details, please check [1] and [2]
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468036/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/463484/

commit_message:
Replace 'manager' with 'os_primary' and 'os_adm' with 'os_admin'

In tempest, alias 'manager' has been moved to 'os_primary'
in version Pike, and it will be removed in version Queens.
This patch is to replace the usage of 'manager' with 'os_primary'.

For other details, please check [1] and [2]
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468036/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/463484/

Change-Id: I9d8de049eb32318de537dd24f4eb837b0b3e43a8

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api-ubuntu-xenial/0330582/ : SUCCESS in 1h 06m 54s
- gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-py3x-api-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-py3x-api-ubuntu-xenial-nv/917ae5c/ : SUCCESS in 1h 04m 55s (non-voting)
- gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-scenario-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-scenario-ubuntu-xenial-nv/692552c/ : SUCCESS in 1h 23m 26s (non-voting)
- gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-py3x-scenario-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-py3x-scenario-ubuntu-xenial-nv/34a0abd/ : SUCCESS in 1h 28m 45s (non-voting)
- gate-octavia-tox-functional-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-octavia-tox-functional-ubuntu-xenial/86e07e1/ : SUCCESS in 6m 57s
- gate-octavia-tox-functional-py35-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-octavia-tox-functional-py35-ubuntu-xenial/e2ef692/ : SUCCESS in 6m 42s'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2017-08-30 07:30:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

On the one hand:
I see the docs were built properly: http://docs-draft.openstack.org/19/499019/1/check/gate-octavia-docs-ubuntu-xenial/671317a//doc/build/html/
I see that the line you removed is absent from OpenStack mainstream projects such as:
Neutron: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/doc/source/conf.py
Nova: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/doc/source/conf.py

On the other hand:
In codesearch I do see it is being used in numerous projects: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=coding%3A%20utf-8&i=nope&files=&repos=

So, I'm not saying that this is not something we should do, but since there is no related bug/mail I'll need more context.
Please elabote in the commit msg why exactly this should be removed."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2017-09-01 15:26:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Fully agree with Nir here.

Even thought we aren't using UTF-8 characters in this document at this time (our titles, etc. are in plain ascii) I don't understand why we need to make this change now."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-05-01 22:47:43.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

A year old and no response, I doubt this is still relevant. If it is, feel free to restore it.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-29 00:22:11.000000000', 'message': "[k8s] Add nginx based ingress controller

Add an nginx based Ingress controller for Kubernetes.

The use case is to provide better support use cases which require either
L4 access or SSL passthrough, which lack proper support in Traefik.

Selection is done via the same label 'ingress_controller' with value
'nginx'. Deployment relies on the upstream nginx-ingress helm chart.

Story: 2005327
Task: 30255
(cherry picked from commit 375fbccf587a9e19afbad4c138977f222023393a)

Conflicts:
       magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/write-heat-params-master.yaml
       magnum/drivers/heat/k8s_fedora_template_def.py
       magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubecluster.yaml
       magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubemaster.yaml

Change-Id: I1db2074fce9d43c03f479a6aaeb4f238d7101555
"}]
commit_message:
[k8s] Add nginx based ingress controller

Add an nginx based Ingress controller for Kubernetes.

The use case is to provide better support use cases which require either
L4 access or SSL passthrough, which lack proper support in Traefik.

Selection is done via the same label 'ingress_controller' with value
'nginx'. Deployment relies on the upstream nginx-ingress helm chart.

Story: 2005327
Task: 30255
(cherry picked from commit 375fbccf587a9e19afbad4c138977f222023393a)

Conflicts:
       magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/write-heat-params-master.yaml
       magnum/drivers/heat/k8s_fedora_template_def.py
       magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubecluster.yaml
       magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubemaster.yaml

Change-Id: I1db2074fce9d43c03f479a6aaeb4f238d7101555

commit_message:
Move subnet postcommit out of transaction for bulk create

For auto-address IPv6 subnets postcommit has update port action
if the net already has ports. This results in
"cannot be called within a transaction" error for bulk IPv6 subnet
create.

Closes-Bug: #1822582
Change-Id: Ia32ec4c11c0793e7df07dcce19c122b3c7f865e1
(cherry picked from commit 14c76d31814b8e696349a1c00ba65ef2919b48af)

commit_message:
Add get_compute_nodes_by_host_or_node()

This patch adds a function, get_compute_nodes_by_host_or_node() to
the host manager to get ComputeNode objects by the given host name
and/or by the given node name.

Change-Id: Ic492766691741e3a8e4938ad90307cb2fe484cc5
Blueprint: use-placement-in-tree

commit_message:
Display project_id for cluster show

It would be useful for cloud admin/ops to display the project_id
in cluster show.

Task: 30676
Story: 2005537

Change-Id: I0f1ae84cf2238ebbf8fc30237d88c7db1eeba6dd
